She describes how the Noyce program enhances a STEM student’s experience in the MAT program by providing real opportunities to understand the benefit of working in a high-needs district and build the competency to do so. She shares how meeting with veteran teachers in both urban and rural high-needs districts allows students to learn the challenges and rewards of working in both settings, providing insight into which environment would be best suited for each individual. In addition she shares how the Noyce program builds a community of graduates and faculty that support each other through the graduates’ year-long student teaching experiences, action research projects, the job search process, and even current teaching positions. It is these experiences collectively that build the graduates competence to work in a high-needs district and ultimately supports them in succeeding as an educator in any setting.

meeting.EventName: Mathematics Education as a Mathematician’s Research Discipline
meeting.EventDescription: Applied mathematicians often participate in collaborative projects with investigators from disciplines close to mathematics as well as more distant disciplines such as medicine and social sciences. In some cases the collaborators may be experimentalists or field workers who provide a complementary and synergistic approach to the mathematics. Mathematicians who are involved in the teaching and learning of mathematics at the university level develop effective teaching practices through experience. These experiences are a starting point (akin to a conjecture) that can be assessed through research studies that take into account students’ cognitive development, learning environments, social contexts and other factors in which mathematics educators have expertise that mathematicians typically do not. It pays off to view mathematics education as any other discipline sufficiently distant from mathematics that collaborative partnerships are necessary in order to have broad impact beyond anecdotal evidence of effective teaching. We describe collaborative projects designed to inform teacher preparation programs on ways to include mathematical modeling in their curriculum.

meeting.EventName: Fourier's Heat Equation: Miniprojects for a Course in Differential Equations
meeting.EventDescription: It is often said that Joseph Fourier gave birth to modern climate science. His 1827 paper ``M´emoire sur les Temp´eratures du Globe Terrestre et des Espaces Plan´etaires" (translated to English as ``On the Temperatures of the Terrestrial Sphere and Interplanetary Space" in [Pierrehumbert, 2004]) contained influential observations concerning climate and energy. Its analysis was based on mathematical results, establishing the diffusion equation, in his earlier ``Analytical Theory of Heat." We present a historically based project for a course in differential equations [Monks, K. M., Fourier's Heat Equation and the Birth of Modern Climate Science, 2021. Differential Equations. 5. https://digitalcommons.ursinus.edu/triumphs\_differ/5]. The goal of the project is to give the reader an insight into the techniques Fourier employed in his work in climate, as it has become the basis of modern thermodynamics and has been enormously consequential in mathematics.

meeting.EventName: Educational Frameworks for Engaging the Next Generation Workforce at the Interface of Mathematics and Biology
meeting.EventDescription: In this talk, we discuss some novel educational frameworks including experiential learning, inquiry-based learning, challenge based learning and interdisciplinary problem-based learning that provide the opportunity to engage students to represent, understand, analyze and solve real world problems at the interface of mathematics and biology. These approaches can help students to become life-long learners going beyond a content-based education in mathematical biology to also include a competency-based training. The talk will present examples of authentic tasks that can help to incorporate a shared collaborative experience with innovative pedagogical practices to advance teaching and learning. The session will also introduce participants to potential funding opportunities available at the interface of mathematics and biology.

meeting.EventName: A Case Study on Undergraduate Math Research That Evolved into Entrepreneurship
Addressing Academic Status via Authentic Mathematical Modeling Tasks
meeting.EventDescription: Mathematical modeling is a process for describing the world with mathematics, as well as a practice for learning mathematics in the K-12 classroom. In this study, I implemented modeling materials from the MODULE(S)${}^2$ Project in a senior-level content course for secondary mathematics pre-service teachers. The diversity of contexts and math concepts in the modeling tasks led to collaborative instructional practices that highlighted students' mathematical strengths and created an equitable learning environment. In particular, the authenticity of the tasks and creativity of projects allowed students to draw on their funds of knowledge and mathematical knowledge bases to decrease issues of academic status. In this presentation, I will share examples of student work to illustrate the benefits of incorporating modeling tasks in undergraduate curricula for mathematics teacher preparation.

meeting.EventName: Using Place-Based Education in Precalculus
meeting.EventDescription: Indigenous cultures have been using mathematics in their lives for generations. In this talk, we present methods of using place-based examples in a precalculus classroom using Native Hawaiian culture. Through these examples, we hope to increase student participation in the classroom from both Indigenous and non-Indigenous students as well as spread awareness of various cultures.

IP1 Opening Remarks and Presentation: Preparing and Supporting Teachers to Include Mathematical Modeling in Their Curriculum
meeting.EventDescription: Students clearly deserve stimulating problem-solving opportunities in which they create and explore mathematical models to address situations relevant and meaningful to them. Yet despite calls to incorporate more modeling activities in our classes, teachers at all levels struggle to put recommendations into action. Since undergraduate mathematics serves as a confluence in the teacher preparation stream, it must include ‘model’ mathematical modeling pedagogy. In this talk, I will share insights my collaborators and I have gained from designing and implementing data driven mathematical modeling activities in undergraduate courses. I will further detail various strategies for engaging undergraduate mathematics faculty as well as prospective and professional secondary teachers in mathematical modeling focused professional development.

meeting.EventName: IP2 Research on Learning and Teaching University Mathematics: Where We Are and Where We Might Go Next
meeting.EventDescription: In this talk I begin with a brief overview of what we know about the teaching and learning of calculus in the United States. In particular, I highlight findings from two large US national studies of the precalculus through calculus sequence . Next, I review what we know about the effects and uptake of research-based instructional strategies at the university level. I then reflect on new directions for the broader field of research in university mathematics education. These new directions include expanding the notion of inquiry, research related to departmental and institutional change, and research that centers issues of equity and social justice.

meeting.EventName: IP3 Education, Data, and Social Justice
meeting.EventDescription: While the importance of data science training has been highlighted by stakeholders across the mathematical sciences, the fusion of data skills with core parts of the curriculum has yet to be fully realized. In parallel to this challenge, the mathematical sciences are struggling with issues of equity, diversity, and inclusion. This talk presents pathways for incorporating data skills into undergraduate mathematics education in ways that support social justice. One pathway is through the classroom. I will present selected examples of course activities such as creation of computational art designed to celebrate artists from marginalized identity groups. A second pathway is through undergraduate research. I will showcase data-intensive student projects, including work on incarceration policy on Rikers Island. Finally, I will highlight resources for instructors who themselves want to grow their data skills and/or their understanding of social justice.

meeting.EventName: IP4 Closing Remarks and Presentation: Toward a Culturally Relevant and Historically Responsive Data Science
meeting.EventDescription: In the expanding discourses around data science and statistical data analysis, less work has been done to make culturally- and historically- centered pedagogies a central area of investigation. To this end, this invited talk will examine seminal theories in education focused on the role of culture and history in teaching and student learning. Within the development of inquiry-based classrooms, these frameworks support our collective knowledge around the role of culture and history in relation to applied mathematics, statistics, and data science education in k-12, postsecondary, and community settings. Moreover, these frameworks can be used to support the ongoing development of data science programs and research-practice partnerships that advance actionable and critical data science practices.

meeting.EventName: JP1 Joint Plenary with the SIAM Annual Meeting AN22: Strengthening and Building Communities among Students, Faculty and the Public
meeting.EventDescription: Given the large percentage of Latino and first-generation college students in the Rio Grande Valley, the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley serves as a hub for preparing the nation’s leadership in STEM disciplines from underrepresented groups. In this talk, we describe efforts to build communities in applied mathematics involving public schools, students and faculty, universities, and the UTRGV Center of Excellence in STEM Education. We will discuss departmental initiatives in mathematics courses that build community among students and faculty, professional development activities and mentorship of college students, and K-12 collaborations.

meeting.EventName: Lunch Break (attendees on their own)
MS1 Extracurricular Training in Industrial Mathematics
meeting.EventDescription: For years, professional and governmental societies have advocated for providing mathematicians with training in industrial mathematics. Successful industrial mathematicians need to be able to quickly assimilate and apply a wide variety of modeling, computational, and data science methods. Given the rigid structure of many mathematics curricula, extracurricular training activities play a key role in supplementing the academic approach to better prepare math students for industrial careers. Such short-term programs allow students to synthesize their mathematical knowledge while developing such "soft skills" as working in teams, making oral presentations, and writing technical reports. The presenters will highlight two long-running summer programs where students work side-by-side with companies on industrial problems: an REU at Worcester Polytechnic Institute which exposes, and the joint Graduate Student Modeling Camp/Mathematical Problems in Industry Workshop program.

meeting.EventName: MS10 Advancing Racial Equity in Applied Mathematics - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Issues of racial equity in the mathematical sciences have become more prominent since the catalyzing events of the summer of 2020. In this minisymposium we invite participants to present, learn and suggest mechanisms, programs or ideas that advance racial equity in the applied mathematics community.
Discussions of racial equity are an important component in any effort to promote justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion at SIAM and the larger applied mathematics community.

meeting.EventName: MS11 Teaching on the Interface of Quantitative Sciences and the Life Sciences
meeting.EventDescription: The need for, and importance of, increased quantitative reasoning in life science education has been well documented in numerous reports such as HHMI’s Scientific Foundations for Future Physicians; AAAS’s Vision and Change; and Biology 2010, a cooperative effort led by the National Research Council. However, implementation has been slowed by disciplinary, institutional and historical challenges, especially when working across departments and across institutions. To address these challenges, there are many active areas of research assessing best practices in developing and evaluating methods of incorporating quantitative reasoning in the life science curriculum. Speakers will highlight current work that advances our understanding of how best to incorporate quantitative reasoning and practices into the life science curriculum, including issues of what quantitative reasoning topics are best suited to the life sciences and in what order; what specific approaches have been most successful in promoting increased quantitative reasoning skills in a biological context; how can we assess changes in quantitative skills in undergraduate life science majors; what challenges have been most difficult to overcome in these efforts; and prospective efforts to confront those challenges.

meeting.EventName: MS12 Innovative Approaches to Undergraduate Research Mentorship - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Undergraduate research in applied mathematics is an important part of training for future scientists, mathematicians, and industry leaders. In this minisymposium, speakers will share innovative approaches to engage undergraduate students in research projects. Talks will highlight creative mentorship practices and examples of projects which have been successful. Innovative practices will range from creating individual/departmental structures to promote equitable research access, to building interdisciplinary/industrial/governmental partnerships. Speakers will represent a wide range of institutions and career stages, and the ideas shared in these sessions will inspire others to implement new and effective practices.

meeting.EventName: MS13 Project-Based Mathematical Modeling, Research, and Teacher Education - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Mathematical modeling is in the unique position of being part of the K-16 curriculum, a topic in undergraduate mathematics, a technique used by professionals, and an active area of research. For this reason, it is important for mathematicians and mathematics educators to come together and advance collaboratively their instruction of a wide range of courses that prepare students for mathematical modeling applications in their future careers, including teacher preparation for K-12 education, consistent with the way practitioners construct and use mathematical models. This session will highlight collaborative research projects focused on modeling research, teacher education, and mathematical pedagogy in undergraduate courses, including practical approaches that engage students in data collection, theoretical, and computational approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS14 Supporting Teaching and Learning Differential Equations Through Modeling
meeting.EventDescription:
It is appropriate and valuable to motivate student learning of applied mathematics through applications! In SIMIODE, an NSF funded community founded in 2013, we support faculty and teachers instructing and students learning differential equations in context in order to bring forth the excitement, intellectual joy, and practice in transferring the mathematics to cognate areas. The SIMIODE Community of Practice has thousands of members, hundreds of teaching and supplemental resources, and practical activities to foster and motivate learning the mathematics of differential equations through modeling.
We give an overview, as well as rich illustrations, of what SIMIODE has to offer in terms of OER resources and activities, e.g., teaching materials, potential modeling activities, forums, newsletter, workshops, EXPO conference, student challenge event SCUDEM, textbook, and much more, as well as examples of the actual teaching and learning process of using modeling in differential equations coursework.

meeting.EventName: MS15 Advancing Racial Equity in Applied Mathematics - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Issues of racial equity in the mathematical sciences have become more prominent since the catalyzing events of the summer of 2020. In this minisymposium we invite participants to present, learn and suggest mechanisms, programs or ideas that advance racial equity in the applied mathematics community.
Discussions of racial equity are an important component in any effort to promote justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion at SIAM and the larger applied mathematics community.

meeting.EventName: MS16 Innovative Approaches to Undergraduate Research Mentorship - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Undergraduate research in applied mathematics is an important part of training for future scientists, mathematicians, and industry leaders. In this minisymposium, speakers will share innovative approaches to engage undergraduate students in research projects. Talks will highlight creative mentorship practices and examples of projects which have been successful. Innovative practices will range from creating individual/departmental structures to promote equitable research access, to building interdisciplinary/industrial/governmental partnerships. Speakers will represent a wide range of institutions and career stages, and the ideas shared in these sessions will inspire others to implement new and effective practices.

meeting.EventName: MS17 Project-Based Learning
meeting.EventDescription: Incorporating class projects into the undergraduate math curriculum has numerous benefits. They create opportunities for students to engage with math content in a deeper and more personalized way, and to understand the applications of the math they learn. Projects also give students practice with technical writing and giving formal presentations. On the other hand, projects can be time-consuming and more subjective to grade as compared to traditional exams. In addition, within the constraints of a course, students must be given more structure as compared to an undergraduate research experience. In this minisymposium, speakers will share their ideas and experiences incorporating projects into their undergraduate math and applied math courses.

meeting.EventName: MS18 Modes of Reasoning About Proof in College Classrooms
meeting.EventDescription: Proofs are at the core of all mathematics, yet proofs are pedagogically challenging for both instructor and student. One reason that proof is challenging to teach and learn is that it is a rich and multifaceted concept. The minisymposium highlights recent advances in characterizing what it means to write and understand proofs and participate in a culture of proving, with an emphasis on classroom applications to improve the teaching of proof. The first talk will focus on the different ways a student can understand a proof, distinguishing between local understandings (why a particular step is valid) and global understanding (how the overarching method in the proof can be used to solve another problem). The development of valid and reliable proof comprehension tests will be discussed. The second talk will highlight the skills involved in proof construction, such as the skills involved in recalling definitions and structuring a proof. There will be a discussion of how these skills can be taught and how they correlate with performance in mathematics courses. The third talk will examine the functions of proof in the undergraduate mathematics classroom. The talk will highlight the explanatory role of proof, and focus on how explanatory proofs can be defined and identified. The fourth talk will discuss the myriad of proving activities, such as conjecturing, generalizing, and exemplifying, and how these activities can be fostered in student-centered classrooms.

meeting.EventName: MS2 NSF RTG Programs in Applied Mathematics and Data Science - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: NSF’s Research Training Groups in the Mathematical Sciences (RTG) program aims to increase the number of well-prepared U.S. citizens, nationals, and permanent residents to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences in academia, government, or industry. In this minisymposium, faculty from RTG programs from a variety of institutions will describe their research activities and models for training students and postdoctoral associates. Topics will include research and educational activity integration, recruitment, mentorship, and undergraduate research engagement. RTG programs in applied mathematics and data science will be the focus of this minisymposium.

meeting.EventName: MS3 STEM Up NY Noyce: Program Values and Why Focus on Rural/Urban Juxtaposition?
meeting.EventDescription: Critical to the retention of STEM teachers in high-need districts is developing an understanding of the culture of both students and the learning environment combined with a strong background in STEM. In this session, we focus on overcoming the challenges in recruiting, training and retaining high-achieving STEM students to work in high-need secondary schools. Exceptional undergraduate STEM students with a passion for teaching are recruited through the NSF Noyce Program at Clarkson University prior to their senior year. The main objective for the program is to support pre-service STEM teachers to develop cultural competence focusing on high-need schools (in urban and rural settings) so that they can appreciate the diversity of students they will work with and therefore better serve the schools and communities. The program offers a significant scholarship for both senior year and through their MAT (Masters of Arts in Teaching) year. We describe the framework of the program, with a focus on curriculum and immersive experiences that guide students in developing their own teaching identities with regards to equity, poverty, and social justice. A graduate student and an undergraduate student share their personal experiences about working with K-12 students and how the program supported them.

meeting.EventName: MS4 Mathematical Modeling Initiatives: An International Perspective
meeting.EventDescription:
<Mathematical modeling has increasingly become a focus of mathematics education worldwide. In 2014 COMAP created the International Mathematical Modeling Challenge (IMMC) to provide teachers the motivation for integrating modeling into the curriculum and students the opportunity to apply their modeling skills. Each country may enter up to two teams of up to four students each. This past year 55 teams from 40 countries participated. The purpose of the Challenge is to encourage changes in school curriculum by demonstrating the power of mathematical modeling. Countries have mobilized to successfully participate, and in several cases conduct their own pre-contests to select the two teams who will participate in the international Challenge.
In this minisymposium, we will first provide an overview and the history of the IMMC. We will present several examples of past Challenge problems and discuss students’ work. Challenge leaders from several participating countries will then describe their efforts in this area and how they are effecting institutional change. Moreover, the speakers will describe the position of mathematical modeling in their respective mathematics education systems.

meeting.EventName: MS5 Building Mathematical Communities from K-12 to Academia
meeting.EventDescription: Building effective communities in mathematics is crucial to recruiting and retaining underrepresented participation at the student and faculty levels. In this minisymposia, we will discuss several instances of building communities in mathematics. Dr. Hand has built a vibrant community of high school students through a summer camp in collaboration with the Tapia Center for Excellence and Equity in Education. Dr. Sifuentes will discuss how he has built communities in the classroom and research lab of diverse mathematicians on the Texas-Mexico border. Finally, Dr. Harris will discuss how she has built communities of mathematics through the Lathisms organization.

meeting.EventName: MS6 Panel: QuantCrit: Thinking Critically about Quantification Methods for Teaching and Social Research
meeting.EventDescription: QuantCrit is a relatively new field, rooted in the traditions of critical inquiry and designed to carefully think through the consequences of the way that data and models are constructed which require the quantification and aggregation of human data. This process of “bucketing and quantification” is typical for the work of applied mathematics. However, as applied mathematicians use their skills in education research or provide classroom examples which involve social dimensions, we need to develop frameworks and tools for understanding how to have conversations about the human dimensions of mathematics. For example - Do we set up our research questions in ways that allow us to examine intersectional issues in the classroom? How do we ask students for demographic information in ways that are validating? Do our models or classroom examples assume gender binary? How might our quantitative methods obscure inequities in student outcomes? Do we interpret observed inequities as gaps or as educational debts? Without these difficult conversations, students could feel their experiences have been erased in the classroom and education research might not elucidate the full picture.

meeting.EventName: MS7 Panel: NSF RTG Programs in Applied Mathematics and Data Science - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: NSF’s Research Training Groups in the Mathematical Sciences (RTG) program aims to increase the number of well-prepared U.S. citizens, nationals, and permanent residents to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences in academia, government, or industry. In this mini-symposium, faculty from RTG programs from a variety of institutions will describe their research activities and models for training students and postdoctoral associates. Topics will include research and educational activity integration, recruitment, mentorship, and undergraduate research engagement. RTG programs in applied mathematics and data science will be the focus of this minisymposium.

meeting.EventName: MS8 Project-Based Mathematical Modeling, Research, and Teacher Education - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Mathematical modeling is in the unique position of being part of the K-16 curriculum, a topic in undergraduate mathematics, a technique used by professionals, and an active area of research. For this reason, it is important for mathematicians and mathematics educators to come together and advance collaboratively their instruction of a wide range of courses that prepare students for mathematical modeling applications in their future careers, including teacher preparation for K-12 education, consistent with the way practitioners construct and use mathematical models. This session will highlight collaborative research projects focused on modeling research, teacher education, and mathematical pedagogy in undergraduate courses, including practical approaches that engage students in data collection, theoretical, and computational approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS9 History of Science and Mathematics in Applied Maths Courses
meeting.EventDescription: The history of math and science provides countless ideas not encountered in standard courses as well as avenues of exploring cultures. History of mathematics courses often focus on mathematics with little reference to the scientific questions that inspired mathematical inquiry or science that was pushed forward by advances in mathematics. Speakers in this minisymposium will present successful methods of integrating math and science history into applied mathematics courses that help students to see math and science as integrated endeavors.

meeting.EventName: MT1 Introduction to COMAP’s Certificate in Modeling (CiM) Program for Educators – Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: During this workshop, we will introduce participants to the CiM program as well as the opportunity to obtain the Modeling Educator Certificate (MEC). Workshop participants will participate in two hour-long sessions where COMAP will expose participants to the material contained within the first two modules of the Modeling for Education course. During module 1, participants will trace a bit of history of educational practices from traditional/computational (#1-15 odd), to “word” problems, to applied problem solving, to “modeling problem.” After completing module 1, every participant will have a better understanding of the philosophy of teaching/learning and framework for applied problem solving and modeling. During module 2, participants will explore a Showcase of (Modeling) Examples to learn how to expose students to various fields, levels of solutions, and types of mathematics involved. In addition to being exposed to the course in-class activities, workshop participants will also experience some of the pre- and post-class activities planned as part of the program. Following the completion of module 2, the workshop will conclude with a discussion about the workshop experience and opportunity to obtain the modeling certificate.

meeting.EventName: MT2 Introduction to COMAP’s Certificate in Modeling (CiM) Program for Educators – Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: During this workshop, we will introduce participants to the CiM program as well as the opportunity to obtain the Modeling Educator Certificate (MEC). Workshop participants will participate in two hour-long sessions where COMAP will expose participants to the material contained within the first two modules of the Modeling for Education course. During module 1, participants will trace a bit of history of educational practices from traditional/computational (#1-15 odd), to “word” problems, to applied problem solving, to “modeling problem.” After completing module 1, every participant will have a better understanding of the philosophy of teaching/learning and framework for applied problem solving and modeling. During module 2, participants will explore a Showcase of (Modeling) Examples to learn how to expose students to various fields, levels of solutions, and types of mathematics involved. In addition to being exposed to the course in-class activities, workshop participants will also experience some of the pre- and post-class activities planned as part of the program. Following the completion of module 2, the workshop will conclude with a discussion about the workshop experience and opportunity to obtain the modeling certificate.
